commentary_on_process:
To solve the problem, I first identified that it was a percentage or proportion problem. Then, I made a list of the percentages of each race in the population and added up the percentages of all the races that make up no more than 1% of the population. The total percentage was 1.7%, which means that there are 3 races that make up no more than 1% of the population. 

To solve the problem better, I could have used a table or chart to organize the given information. This would have made it easier to see which races make up no more than 1% of the population and to add up their percentages.
final_answer: There are 3 races that make up no more than 1% of the population.
problem_text:
Context:
At the 2000 census The population density was 7,183.6 inhabitants per square mile (2,773.9/km²). There were 75,662 housing units at an average density of 2,866.8 per square mile (1,107.0/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 79.2% Race (United States Census), 0.8% Race (United States Census) or Race (United States Census), 0.7% Race (United States Census), 9.3% Race (United States Census), 0.2% Race (United States Census), 5.8% from Race (United States Census), and 3.9% from two or more races. 14.7% of the population were Hispanics in the United States or Race (United States Census) of any race.

Question:
How many races made up no more than 1% of the population?
